canonical_explanation.text:
The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. Cell theory, proposed by Schleiden and Schwann and later modified by Rudolf Virchow, states that all living organisms are composed of cells and products of cells, and that all cells arise from pre-existing cells. Cells are broadly classified into prokaryotic and eukaryotic types. Prokaryotic cells (e.g., bacteria, cyanobacteria) lack a well-defined nucleus; their genetic material lies in a nucleoid region and is not bound by a nuclear membrane. They possess 70S ribosomes, a cell wall (usually of peptidoglycan), and may contain plasmids, mesosomes, and flagella. Eukaryotic cells (found in protists, fungi, plants, and animals) have a well-organised nucleus with a nuclear envelope, membrane-bound organelles, and 80S ribosomes.
The plasma membrane follows the fluid mosaic model proposed by Singer and Nicolson (1972), in which a lipid bilayer of phospholipids with embedded integral and peripheral proteins provides selective permeability. Transport across the membrane occurs via passive means (diffusion, osmosis, facilitated diffusion) and active transport requiring ATP. Eukaryotic cells contain an elaborate endomembrane system comprising the endoplasmic reticulum (rough and smooth), Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and vacuoles. Mitochondria are double-membrane-bound organelles with cristae and matrix, possessing their own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes; they are the sites of aerobic respiration. Chloroplasts, found in plant cells, have thylakoids organised into grana and a stroma, and also contain their own DNA and ribosomes. The cytoskeleton is composed of microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments, providing structural support, motility, and intracellular transport. Cilia and flagella display a characteristic 9+2 arrangement of microtubules. Centrioles have a 9+0 arrangement (nine triplets, no central pair) and are involved in cell division.
rules: Cell theory: all living organisms are composed of cells; all cells arise from pre-existing cells (omnis cellula e cellula — Virchow).
Prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus and organelles; genetic material is in the nucleoid region.
Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes (50S + 30S), while eukaryotes have 80S ribosomes (60S + 40S) in the cytoplasm.
The fluid mosaic model (Singer and Nicolson, 1972) describes the plasma membrane as a lipid bilayer with floating proteins.
Transport across membranes: passive (diffusion, osmosis, facilitated) and active (requires ATP, against concentration gradient).
The endomembrane system includes ER, Golgi complex, lysosomes, and vacuoles — all functionally connected.
Mitochondria and chloroplasts are semi-autonomous organelles with their own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes.
Mitochondria have an inner membrane folded into cristae; the matrix contains enzymes for the Krebs cycle.
Chloroplasts contain thylakoids (stacked into grana) and stroma; light reactions occur in thylakoids, Calvin cycle in stroma.
Lysosomes contain hydrolytic enzymes and are called 'suicidal bags' of the cell.
Cilia and flagella have a 9+2 axonemal arrangement of microtubules; centrioles have a 9+0 arrangement of triplet microtubules.
The cytoskeleton comprises microtubules (tubulin), microfilaments (actin), and intermediate filaments — supporting shape, motility, and transport.

questions.question_text: Who proposed the cell theory?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell theory was proposed by Matthias Schleiden (for plants, 1838) and Theodor Schwann (for animals, 1839). They stated that all living organisms are composed of cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Robert Hooke discovered cells but did not formulate the cell theory. Virchow later modified it by adding that cells arise from pre-existing cells. Watson and Crick are known for the DNA double helix model.

questions.question_text: The modification of cell theory stating 'omnis cellula e cellula' was given by:
questions.explanation_correct: Rudolf Virchow (1855) modified the cell theory by stating 'omnis cellula e cellula', meaning all cells arise from pre-existing cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Schleiden and Schwann proposed the original cell theory. Robert Brown discovered the nucleus. It was Virchow who added the idea that cells originate only from pre-existing cells.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of prokaryotic cells?

options.text: Nucleoid region without a nuclear envelope

questions.explanation_correct: Prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus. Their genetic material (usually a single circular DNA) lies in the nucleoid region, which is not enclosed by a nuclear envelope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Membrane-bound nucleus, 80S ribosomes, and mitochondria are features of eukaryotic cells. Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes and lack membrane-bound organelles.

questions.question_text: Plasmids are:

options.text: Small circular extra-chromosomal DNA in bacteria
Protein bodies found in the cytoplasm

questions.explanation_correct: Plasmids are small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecules found in bacteria, separate from the main chromosomal DNA. They often carry genes for antibiotic resistance and are used in genetic engineering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plasmids are not membrane-bound organelles or protein bodies. They are extrachromosomal DNA elements found specifically in prokaryotic cells.

questions.question_text: A scientist discovers a unicellular organism with a cell wall made of peptidoglycan, 70S ribosomes, and no membrane-bound organelles. This organism is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: Peptidoglycan cell wall, 70S ribosomes, and absence of membrane-bound organelles are characteristic features of bacteria (prokaryotic cells).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fungi have chitin cell walls and are eukaryotic. Plant cells have cellulose walls and are eukaryotic. Protists are also eukaryotic with 80S ribosomes. The described features point to a prokaryotic bacterium.

questions.question_text: Which of the following structures in prokaryotic cells is/are functionally similar to mitochondria in eukaryotic cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Mesosomes are infoldings of the plasma membrane in prokaryotes that are thought to play a role in cellular respiration, DNA replication, and cell division — functions analogous to those of mitochondria in eukaryotes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis. Plasmids carry extra genetic information. Inclusion bodies store reserve materials. Mesosomes are the structures analogous to mitochondria in terms of respiratory function.

questions.question_text: Mycoplasma differs from other bacteria in that it:
questions.explanation_correct: Mycoplasma is the smallest known cell that can survive without oxygen. It is unique among bacteria as it lacks a cell wall entirely, which makes it resistant to antibiotics like penicillin that target cell wall synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mycoplasma is a prokaryote, so it does not have a well-defined nucleus, 80S ribosomes, or membrane-bound organelles. Its distinguishing feature is the absence of a cell wall.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements:
(i) Prokaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes.
(ii) Mesosomes are formed by extensions of the plasma membrane in bacteria.
(iii) Mycoplasma is the smallest cell and lacks a cell wall.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (i) is incorrect — prokaryotic cells have 70S ribosomes (50S + 30S), not 80S. Statement (ii) is correct — mesosomes are infoldings of the bacterial plasma membrane. Statement (iii) is correct — Mycoplasma is the smallest known cell and lacks a cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes, statement (i) is wrong. Only statements (ii) and (iii) are factually correct.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature that distinguishes a prokaryotic cell from a eukaryotic cell?
questions.explanation_correct: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells possess a cell membrane (plasma membrane). Therefore, the presence of a cell membrane does not distinguish prokaryotes from eukaryotes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Absence of a defined nucleus, absence of membrane-bound organelles, and 70S ribosomes are all features specific to prokaryotes that help distinguish them from eukaryotes. The cell membrane is present in both types.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Robert Hooke is credited with the discovery of cells.
Reason (R): He observed living cells from cork tissue under a microscope and coined the term 'cell'.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is true — Robert Hooke (1665) discovered cells by examining cork tissue. However, the reason is false because Hooke actually observed dead cells (empty cell walls), not living cells. He coined the term 'cellula' (cell) based on the box-like compartments he saw.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hooke did discover cells, but what he observed in cork were dead, empty cell walls, not living cells. Leeuwenhoek was the first to observe living cells (which he called 'animalcules').

questions.question_text: The fluid mosaic model of the plasma membrane was proposed by:
questions.explanation_correct: The fluid mosaic model was proposed by S.J. Singer and G.L. Nicolson in 1972. It describes the plasma membrane as a lipid bilayer with proteins embedded in it (integral) or attached to the surface (peripheral).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Robertson proposed the unit membrane model. Danielli and Davson proposed the sandwich model. Schleiden and Schwann proposed the cell theory. The fluid mosaic model is credited to Singer and Nicolson.

questions.question_text: The major lipid component of the plasma membrane is:
questions.explanation_correct: Phospholipids are the major lipid component of the plasma membrane. They are amphipathic molecules with a hydrophilic head (phosphate group) and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails, forming the characteristic lipid bilayer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While cholesterol and glycolipids are also present in the membrane, phospholipids form the bulk of the lipid bilayer. Triglycerides are storage lipids, not structural components of the plasma membrane.

questions.question_text: Which type of transport across the plasma membrane requires carrier proteins but does NOT require energy?
questions.explanation_correct: Facilitated diffusion is a passive process (no ATP required) in which molecules move down their concentration gradient with the help of carrier proteins or channel proteins present in the membrane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active transport requires both carrier proteins and ATP. Simple diffusion does not require carrier proteins. Endocytosis is an active, energy-dependent process involving membrane engulfment.

questions.question_text: In the fluid mosaic model, integral proteins:

options.text: Are loosely attached to the outer surface of the membrane
Are partially or completely embedded in the lipid bilayer
Are found only in prokaryotic cells

questions.explanation_correct: Integral (intrinsic) proteins are partially or completely embedded in the lipid bilayer. Some span the entire membrane (transmembrane proteins) and function as channels or carriers for transport.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Proteins loosely attached to the surface are peripheral (extrinsic) proteins. Integral proteins are firmly embedded in the lipid bilayer, not floating in the cytoplasm, and are found in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic membranes.

questions.question_text: A cell is placed in a hypertonic solution. Which of the following will occur?

options.text: The cell will swell due to water entry
The cell will shrink due to water loss (exosmosis)
There will be no net movement of water

questions.explanation_correct: In a hypertonic solution, the solute concentration outside the cell is higher than inside. Water moves out of the cell by osmosis (exosmosis), causing the cell to shrink. In plant cells, this leads to plasmolysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Swelling occurs in a hypotonic solution (endosmosis). No net movement occurs in an isotonic solution. The cell wall does not dissolve in a hypertonic environment; instead, the protoplast shrinks away from the cell wall.

questions.question_text: The Na⁺/K⁺ pump in animal cells is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: The Na⁺/K⁺ pump actively transports 3 Na⁺ ions out and 2 K⁺ ions into the cell against their concentration gradients, using energy from ATP hydrolysis. This is a classic example of active transport.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion do not require ATP and occur along the concentration gradient. Osmosis involves the movement of water, not ions. The Na⁺/K⁺ pump requires ATP and moves ions against their gradients.

questions.question_text: Why is the plasma membrane described as 'selectively permeable'?

options.text: It allows all molecules to pass through freely
It blocks all molecules from entering or leaving the cell
It allows only certain molecules to pass through based on size, charge, and polarity
It permits only water molecules to cross

questions.explanation_correct: The plasma membrane is selectively permeable because its lipid bilayer with embedded proteins allows only specific molecules to pass through, depending on their size, charge, polarity, and the presence of specific transport proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The membrane does not allow all molecules freely nor does it block everything. It is not exclusively permeable to water. Its selective permeability is a key feature that maintains cellular homeostasis.

questions.question_text:
Match the following types of membrane transport with their characteristics:
(i) Simple diffusion — (a) Requires ATP, moves against gradient
(ii) Facilitated diffusion — (b) No carrier, moves along gradient
(iii) Active transport — (c) Uses carrier proteins, no ATP required
Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Simple diffusion occurs along the concentration gradient without carrier proteins (b). Facilitated diffusion uses carrier or channel proteins but does not require ATP (c). Active transport requires ATP and moves substances against the concentration gradient (a).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct associations are based on standard membrane transport mechanisms. Simple diffusion needs no carriers, facilitated diffusion uses carriers passively, and active transport uses carriers with ATP expenditure.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): The quasi-fluid nature of lipids in the plasma membrane enables lateral movement of proteins.
Reason (R): Phospholipids in the membrane can move laterally within their monolayer.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. The fluid nature of the lipid bilayer allows phospholipids to move laterally, and this fluidity enables the embedded proteins to move within the membrane, supporting the fluid mosaic model.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fluidity of the membrane is well established by the fluid mosaic model. Phospholipids do move laterally, and this lateral movement of lipids directly allows proteins embedded in the bilayer to also move, making R the correct explanation for A.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes endocytosis?

options.text: Release of cellular material outside the cell
Uptake of material into the cell by invagination of the plasma membrane to form vesicles
Diffusion of gases across the plasma membrane

questions.explanation_correct: Endocytosis is the process by which cells internalise substances by engulfing them with the plasma membrane, forming membrane-bound vesicles. It includes phagocytosis (cell eating) and pinocytosis (cell drinking).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Release of material is exocytosis. Diffusion of gases is a passive process. Movement of water through aquaporins is osmosis/facilitated diffusion. Endocytosis specifically involves membrane invagination and vesicle formation.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are called the 'powerhouse of the cell' because they are the primary sites of aerobic respiration, producing ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the energy currency of the cell, through oxidative phosphorylation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chloroplasts are the sites of photosynthesis. The Golgi apparatus is involved in packaging and secretion. The ER is involved in synthesis and transport. Mitochondria are specifically called the powerhouse due to ATP generation.

questions.question_text: Lysosomes are called 'suicidal bags' because they:

options.text: Contain hydrolytic enzymes that can digest the cell itself if released

questions.explanation_correct: Lysosomes contain powerful hydrolytic enzymes (lipases, proteases, carbohydrases, etc.) that operate at acidic pH. If the lysosomal membrane ruptures, these enzymes can digest the cell's own components, leading to autolysis — hence the name 'suicidal bags'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy production is the function of mitochondria. Protein synthesis occurs on ribosomes. Genetic material is stored in the nucleus. Lysosomes are specifically known for their digestive enzymes and the potential for autolysis.

questions.question_text: Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) differs from smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) in that RER has:

options.text: No connection with the nuclear membrane

questions.explanation_correct: Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) has ribosomes attached to its cytoplasmic surface, giving it a 'rough' appearance. These ribosomes are the sites of protein synthesis. SER lacks ribosomes and is involved in lipid synthesis and detoxification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lipid synthesis and detoxification are functions of SER. Both RER and SER can be connected to the nuclear membrane. The defining feature of RER is the presence of ribosomes on its surface.

questions.question_text: The Golgi apparatus is primarily involved in:

options.text: Packaging, modification, and dispatch of materials

questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi apparatus (Golgi complex) is involved in the packaging, modification (glycosylation, phosphorylation), and dispatch of proteins and lipids synthesised in the ER. It also forms lysosomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cellular respiration occurs in mitochondria. Photosynthesis occurs in chloroplasts. DNA replication occurs in the nucleus. The Golgi apparatus is the cell's packaging and distribution centre.

questions.question_text: Mitochondria and chloroplasts are called semi-autonomous organelles because they:

options.text: Can survive independently outside the cell
Possess their own DNA and ribosomes and can synthesise some of their own proteins
Do not require nuclear genes for any function

questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria and chloroplasts are termed semi-autonomous because they possess their own circular DNA, 70S ribosomes, and can carry out transcription and translation to produce some of their own proteins. However, they still depend on nuclear DNA for many proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They cannot survive independently outside the cell. They do require nuclear genes for most of their proteins. Both are double-membrane-bound organelles. Their semi-autonomy is due to possessing their own genetic material and protein synthesis machinery.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organelles is NOT part of the endomembrane system?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are not part of the endomembrane system. The endomembrane system includes the ER, Golgi complex, lysosomes, and vacuoles, which are functionally connected through vesicle transport. Mitochondria have their own independent origin (endosymbiotic origin).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ER, Golgi complex, and lysosomes are all part of the endomembrane system, functioning as an interconnected network for synthesis, modification, packaging, and transport of cellular products.

questions.question_text: In chloroplasts, the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis take place in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The light-dependent reactions (light reactions) of photosynthesis occur in the thylakoid membranes, where photosystems, electron transport chain components, and ATP synthase are embedded. The stroma is the site of the Calvin cycle (light-independent reactions).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stroma is the site of the Calvin cycle (dark reactions). The outer and inner membranes of the chloroplast envelope are not the primary sites for photosynthetic reactions. The thylakoid membrane houses the photosynthetic machinery.

questions.question_text: The inner membrane of a mitochondrion is folded into structures called:
questions.explanation_correct: The inner membrane of the mitochondrion forms finger-like infoldings called cristae, which increase the surface area for oxidative phosphorylation and ATP production. The enzymes of the electron transport chain are located on the cristae.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thylakoids are found in chloroplasts. Cisternae are flattened membrane discs in the ER and Golgi. Lamellae are unstacked thylakoid membranes in chloroplasts. Cristae are specifically the folds of the inner mitochondrial membrane.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following organelles:
(i) Mitochondria
(ii) Chloroplast
(iii) Ribosome
(iv) Golgi apparatus
Which of the above contain their own DNA?
questions.explanation_correct: Only mitochondria and chloroplasts possess their own circular DNA (similar to prokaryotic DNA). Ribosomes and the Golgi apparatus do not have their own DNA. This supports the endosymbiotic theory of their origin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ribosomes are composed of rRNA and proteins but do not carry DNA. The Golgi apparatus is part of the endomembrane system and lacks its own genome. Only mitochondria and chloroplasts are semi-autonomous with their own DNA.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of organelles involved in the synthesis and secretion of a protein from a cell?
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are synthesised on ribosomes attached to the RER. The proteins are then transported to the Golgi apparatus for modification and packaging into vesicles, which fuse with the plasma membrane for secretion (exocytosis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: SER is involved in lipid synthesis, not protein synthesis. Lysosomes are not part of the secretory pathway. The correct sequence follows the endomembrane pathway: Ribosome → RER → Golgi → Plasma membrane.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Ribosomes found in mitochondria are 70S type.
Reason (R): Mitochondria are believed to have evolved from free-living prokaryotic ancestors.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Mitochondrial ribosomes are 70S type (like prokaryotic ribosomes). This supports the endosymbiotic theory, which proposes that mitochondria evolved from ancestral prokaryotic organisms engulfed by a host cell. The 70S ribosomes are a relic of this prokaryotic ancestry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The presence of 70S ribosomes in mitochondria is well established and is directly explained by their proposed prokaryotic evolutionary origin (endosymbiotic theory proposed by Lynn Margulis).

questions.question_text: The nucleus is bounded by a double membrane called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The nucleus is bounded by a nuclear envelope, which consists of two parallel membranes with a perinuclear space between them. Nuclear pores in the envelope regulate the transport of materials between the nucleus and cytoplasm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tonoplast is the membrane surrounding the vacuole. The cell wall is external to the plasma membrane. The plasma membrane surrounds the entire cell. The nuclear envelope is the specific double membrane enclosing the nucleus.

questions.question_text: The cytoskeleton of a eukaryotic cell is composed of:
questions.explanation_correct: The cytoskeleton is a network of protein filaments comprising microtubules (made of tubulin), microfilaments (made of actin), and intermediate filaments. It provides structural support, aids in cell motility, and facilitates intracellular transport.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cellulose and pectin are components of the plant cell wall. Phospholipids and cholesterol form the cell membrane. Histones are nuclear proteins associated with DNA. The cytoskeleton is specifically made of protein filaments.

questions.question_text: Cilia and flagella have a characteristic axonemal arrangement of microtubules described as:
questions.explanation_correct: Cilia and flagella have an axoneme with a 9+2 arrangement — nine peripheral doublets of microtubules surrounding two central singlet microtubules. This arrangement is essential for their beating movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 9+0 arrangement (nine triplets, no central pair) is found in centrioles and basal bodies, not in the axoneme of cilia and flagella. The 9+2 pattern is the characteristic arrangement of cilia and flagella.

questions.question_text: Centrioles are found in:
questions.explanation_correct: Centrioles are found in most animal cells and some lower plant cells. They are cylindrical structures with a 9+0 arrangement of microtubule triplets and play a role in cell division by forming the spindle apparatus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher plant cells lack centrioles. Prokaryotic cells do not possess centrioles. Not all fungal cells have centrioles. Centrioles are primarily a feature of animal cells.

questions.question_text: Peroxisomes contain enzymes that are primarily involved in:

options.text: Oxidation reactions, including the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide

questions.explanation_correct: Peroxisomes are microbodies that contain oxidative enzymes such as catalase and peroxidase. They are involved in the oxidation of fatty acids and amino acids, and catalase breaks down the toxic hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) produced during these reactions into water and oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protein synthesis occurs on ribosomes. DNA replication occurs in the nucleus. Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm. Peroxisomes are specifically involved in oxidation reactions and detoxification of hydrogen peroxide.

questions.question_text: A drug that disrupts microtubule assembly would most directly affect which of the following cellular processes?
questions.explanation_correct: Cilia and flagella are composed of microtubules arranged in a 9+2 pattern. Disruption of microtubule assembly would directly impair the formation and movement of cilia and flagella, as well as spindle formation during cell division.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glycolysis does not depend on microtubules. Transcription involves RNA polymerase, not microtubules. Lipid synthesis in SER is independent of microtubule assembly. Microtubule disruption primarily affects motility and cell division.

questions.question_text: The basal body of a cilium is structurally similar to:
questions.explanation_correct: The basal body of a cilium or flagellum is structurally identical to a centriole, with a 9+0 arrangement of microtubule triplets. The basal body acts as the organising centre from which the axoneme of the cilium or flagellum extends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis. Lysosomes contain digestive enzymes. The nucleolus is the site of rRNA synthesis. The basal body shares the 9+0 triplet microtubule structure with the centriole.

questions.question_text: Microfilaments are made up of the protein:
questions.explanation_correct: Microfilaments (actin filaments) are composed of the protein actin. They are the thinnest elements of the cytoskeleton and are involved in cell movement, muscle contraction (along with myosin), cytokinesis, and maintenance of cell shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tubulin is the protein that forms microtubules. Keratin is an intermediate filament protein found in epithelial cells. Myosin is a motor protein that interacts with actin but does not form microfilaments. Microfilaments are specifically made of actin.

questions.question_text: Glyoxysomes are microbodies found in plant cells, particularly in:
questions.explanation_correct: Glyoxysomes are specialised microbodies found in the cells of germinating seeds. They contain enzymes of the glyoxylate cycle, which converts stored fats (lipids) into carbohydrates (sucrose) for use by the growing seedling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glyoxysomes are not typically prominent in leaf mesophyll cells, root hairs, or guard cells. They are specifically associated with fat-storing seeds during germination, where they play a crucial role in fat-to-sugar conversion.

questions.question_text:
Match the following structures with their microtubule arrangements:
(i) Cilia — (a) 9+0 triplet arrangement
(ii) Centriole — (b) 9+2 doublet arrangement
Select the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Cilia have a 9+2 arrangement (nine peripheral doublets + two central singlets) in their axoneme. Centrioles have a 9+0 arrangement of nine triplet microtubules with no central microtubules. Hence, (i)-(b) and (ii)-(a).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 9+2 arrangement is specific to the axoneme of cilia and flagella, while the 9+0 arrangement of triplets is specific to centrioles and basal bodies. They should not be confused.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Higher plant cells can undergo cell division despite the absence of centrioles.
Reason (R): In higher plant cells, the spindle apparatus is formed by microtubules organised by other microtubule-organising centres.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Higher plant cells lack centrioles but can still divide because their spindle fibres are organised by other microtubule-organising centres (such as the polar organisers). The reason correctly explains how division occurs without centrioles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher plant cells do indeed lack centrioles and still divide successfully. The spindle is formed by microtubules organised from polar caps or other organising centres, which is the correct explanation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct difference between cilia and flagella?

options.text: Cilia are longer and fewer; flagella are shorter and more numerous
Cilia are shorter and more numerous; flagella are longer and fewer in number
Cilia have a 9+0 arrangement; flagella have a 9+2 arrangement
Cilia are found only in prokaryotes; flagella are found only in eukaryotes

questions.explanation_correct: Cilia are shorter (5–10 µm) and present in large numbers on the cell surface, beating in a coordinated manner. Flagella are longer (up to 150 µm) and are fewer in number (usually 1–4), producing undulatory movements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cilia are shorter, not longer. Both cilia and flagella have the 9+2 axonemal arrangement. Both can be found in eukaryotic cells (prokaryotic flagella have a different structure entirely).

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms is an exception to the cell theory?
questions.explanation_correct: Viruses are considered exceptions to the cell theory because they are acellular — they lack a cellular structure and cannot reproduce on their own. They are obligate intracellular parasites and are not considered truly living by many biologists.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba, bacteria, and Paramecium are all cellular organisms and conform to the cell theory. Viruses, being acellular entities, are the notable exceptions.

questions.question_text: Glycoproteins and glycolipids on the outer surface of the plasma membrane are important for:
questions.explanation_correct: Glycoproteins and glycolipids on the extracellular surface of the plasma membrane form the glycocalyx. They play crucial roles in cell-to-cell recognition, cell signalling, immune response, and tissue formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ATP synthesis occurs in mitochondria. DNA replication takes place in the nucleus. Protein folding occurs in the ER. The sugar-containing molecules on the cell surface are specifically involved in recognition and communication.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is involved in the formation of the cell plate during cytokinesis in plant cells?
questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi apparatus produces vesicles containing cell wall materials (polysaccharides) that fuse at the centre of the dividing plant cell to form the cell plate during cytokinesis. This cell plate eventually develops into the new cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ER is involved in synthesis but not directly in cell plate formation. Mitochondria provide energy but do not form the cell plate. Lysosomes are involved in digestion. The Golgi apparatus is the primary organelle contributing to cell plate formation.

questions.question_text: The vacuolar membrane in plant cells is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The membrane surrounding the central vacuole in plant cells is called the tonoplast. It facilitates the transport of ions and other substances into the vacuole and helps maintain turgor pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plasmalemma is another name for the plasma membrane. The nuclear envelope surrounds the nucleus. The glycocalyx is the sugar coat on the cell surface. Tonoplast is the specific term for the vacuolar membrane.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is common to both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Ribosomes are present in both prokaryotic (70S) and eukaryotic (80S) cells. They are non-membrane-bound organelles essential for protein synthesis. All other listed structures are found only in eukaryotic cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nuclear envelope, mitochondria, and endoplasmic reticulum are membrane-bound structures found exclusively in eukaryotic cells. Ribosomes are the only organelles from the given options that are present in both cell types.

questions.question_text: Grana in chloroplasts are:
questions.explanation_correct: Grana (singular: granum) are stacks of disc-shaped thylakoids within the chloroplast. Adjacent grana are connected by stroma lamellae (intergranal lamellae). Grana are the sites where the light reactions of photosynthesis occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Folds of the inner membrane are cristae (in mitochondria). Grana are not enzyme vesicles or starch granules. They are specifically stacks of thylakoid membranes in the chloroplast.

questions.question_text: Which component of the cytoskeleton is responsible for providing mechanical strength and maintaining cell shape in epithelial cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Intermediate filaments (such as keratin filaments in epithelial cells) provide mechanical strength and help maintain cell shape. They are more stable and less dynamic than microtubules and microfilaments, and resist tensile forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Microtubules are mainly involved in intracellular transport and cell division. Microfilaments are involved in cell motility and muscle contraction. Flagella are locomotory structures. Intermediate filaments are the cytoskeletal elements that provide mechanical strength.
